abstract_summ: This study aimed to establish an early screening model to distinguish COVID-19 pneumonia from Influenza-A viral pneumonia and healthy cases with pulmonary CT images using deep learning techniques.CONCLUSIONS The ConvNet was able to distinguish the COVID-19 images among non-COVID-19 images, namely bacterial and viral pneumonia as well as normal X-ray images.This study aimed to establish an early screening model to distinguish COVID-19 pneumonia from IAVP and healthy cases through pulmonary CT images using deep learning techniques.An average running speed of 20.3 s ± 5.8 per case demonstrated the algorithm was much faster than the residents in assessing CT images (all p < 0.017).RESULTS: Of 96 patients, 88 had pneumonia lesions on CT images and 8 had no abnormities on CT images.
title_summ: Classification of Coronavirus Images using Shrunken FeaturesDifferentiating COVID-19 from other types of pneumonia with convolutional neural networksImproved deep learning model for differentiating novel coronavirus pneumonia and influenza pneumoniaHypergraph Learning for Identification of COVID-19 with CT ImagingCoronavirus (COVID-19) Classification using Deep Features Fusion and Ranking TechniqueDeep Learning System to Screen Coronavirus Disease 2019 PneumoniaA deep learning approach to characterize 2019 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pneumonia in chest CT imagesA Deep Learning System to Screen Novel Coronavirus Disease 2019 PneumoniaRecognition of COVID-19 disease from X-ray images by hybrid model consisting of 2D curvelet transform, chaotic salp swarm algorithm and deep learning technique
title_abstract_phrases: This study aimed to establish an early screening model to distinguish COVID-19 pneumonia from Influenza-A viral pneumonia and healthy cases with pulmonary CT images using deep learning techniques.CONCLUSIONS The ConvNet was able to distinguish the COVID-19 images among non-COVID-19 images, namely bacterial and viral pneumonia as well as normal X-ray images.This study aimed to establish an early screening model to distinguish COVID-19 pneumonia from IAVP and healthy cases through pulmonary CT images using deep learning techniques.An average running speed of 20.3 s ± 5.8 per case demonstrated the algorithm was much faster than the residents in assessing CT images (all p < 0.017).A deep learning approach to characterize 2019 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pneumonia in chest CT imagesOBJECTIVES: To utilize a deep learning model for automatic detection of abnormalities in chest CT images from COVID-19 patients and compare its quantitative determination performance with radiological residents.
